ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I had already seen a lot of the info (diff eq, neural modeling, stochastic processes) but I enjoyed the treatment of them in this class.
I learned more about modeling biological systems. From neuronal modeling to E. coli run and tumble modeling, we've really come a long way. We used a lot of MATLAB and learned a lot of cool models.

I developed a big-picture understanding of modeling biological systems as well as an introduction to coding in MATLAB. I really liked how the class was divided into three different applications, so we got a taste of a range of different systems.

Use of MATLAB. Topics: Stability/instability of systems using linear algebra, how oscillations in biological systems work via feedback systems, modeling the action potential, circuitry, and stochasticity.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 4 weeks on each unit certainly wasnt long enoughI think 2 for 6 would be better.
I really loved this course! Strengths include the teachers and TA's.

Strengths: good introduction to modeling, very nice, thoughtful professors and extremely kind and helpful TA's,  

Weaknesses: the nuances of the class require knowledge of probability theory, circuitry, diff EQs, and linear algebra - none of which are prerequisites for the course. I ended up with more of an overall big-picture understanding and was unable to understand every detail or derivation - nevertheless not sure how necessary that understanding is anyway

While having three different lecturers made the class very engaging and exposed us to many different perspectives in biological systems, I wish their work was coordinated a bit more so that the psets and exercises would have a similar level of difficulty across all three.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the "share-screen" tool was a really helpful way to discuss code.
Mostly everything was successful. The zoom lecture format worked fine  - sometimes the video quality was not so great but occasional technical difficulties are to be expected.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is definitely great if you want advanced knowledge on modeling and have some experience with MATLAB and want to expand on it. However, the coding component in this course can be a little bit difficulty if you are just getting adjusted to MATLAB.
Yes very much so! I'm a person who really likes math and also really likes bio and both this class and MBS part I brought together these two interests of mine.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in a big-picture introduction to modeling. 
The class also just has students with a wide variety of backgrounds/experiences (grad students, undergrads, math/physics vs. biology background) so it is interesting to learn from others in the class. 
However, students with a math/physics background will understand more of the derivations/small details than the students with the biology background.

Yesif youre looking to learn about computational bio/neurobio work and have some computational background (just so you arent very lost when we use things such as for loops), then this class is a wonderful class for providing intuition about biological systems and for teaching you how to build mathematical models for them.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had section twice a week with the best TA's in the world!
